title: Please help identify 80s romance font
content:
Please help us identify this font used on 80s romance novel. We are looking for the font used for "Shirley Conran" and "Savages" Thank you!!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013152216im_/http:/typophile.com/files/savages%20conran_6224.jpg)
author: publicationstudio

comments.content:
I suspect this is something created as a private font to reinforce the product image of the publishers line of romance novels.  
The terminals for both fonts are some sort of a swoosh design -- perhaps to suggest romance. The angled font seems to be a tweeked version of the top font.  
Some of the ideas found in the font date back to 19th century designs.  
Note the R with a sharp angled shoulder on the leg. This is found in at least one readily available font, [ITC Tiffany Heavy](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013152216/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/itc-tiffany/heavy/glyphs.html) designed by Edward Benguiat in 1974 based in part on Ronaldson, a very popular 19th century font with huge serifs on the arms. Canada Type has revived [Ronaldson](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013152216/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/ronaldson/), cut by Alexander Kay for MacKellar in 1884 and designed by Rebecca Alaccari in 2008.  
The huge serifs on L & E in your image could have been adapted from the Ronaldson/Tiffany design by making the serif alignment more vertical and clipping off the spurs protuding below the baseline and above the caps height.  
Don

The swoosh terminals are a rip from the "smooth as butter" fonts such as [Tartine Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013152216/http:/www.identifont.com/list?3+FF%20Tartine%20Script%20Bold+0+27MD+1+EI4+2+2B0Z+2+2GBG+4+IID+4+EI8+4+325F+7+1WQ2+7+HI0+8+2P02+8+MU6+8+MRZ+8+72R+8+DV6+8+2OV1+8+2XE7+8+1ZO9+8+CPQ+8+2P33+8+2Y6H+8+3259+10+O8M+10+2Z4K+10+LUE+10+5Z5+10+LUG+10+7IR+10+MUB+10+27IC+10+2HB+10).  
This is a true Frankenfont!  
Don

Love this Frankenfont!  
The S and C with "smooth as butter" swoosh terminals were previously used by the publisher to spell the author's name in a very different font.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013152216im_/http:/typophile.com/files/crimson_5376.jpg)
  
The cover designer has a real post modern flair for font style fusion.  
Don
